page.title: 14 TRENT AND MERSEY CANAL
page.content: In 1766,the Trent and Mersey Canal Act was passed by Parliament.James Brindley was appointed engineer of the new canal.In 1777 the canal was opened for the transport of industrial materials. It is now mainly used for holidays.At many of the canal's junctions,boats can be hired out for holiday uses.The stretch of the canal from Weston to Great Haywood Junction is very scenic and good for holidays. The Trent and Mersey Canal is much favoured for its fishing.Some common fishes in the canal are:perch,roach and carp. In the stretch from Weston to Great Haywood Junction,there are 6 bridges and 2 locks.The 2 locks have a total height of 15'9".The bridges were built for horses to cross over the canal when the tow-path changed sides.
